H0.text: Electrons are the same number in the nuclei of all atoms of an element.

H1.text: Isotopes are atoms of an element that have in their nuclei the same number of protons.

H2.text: Molecules are the same number in the nuclei of all atoms of an element.

H3.text: Protons are the same number in the nuclei of all atoms of an element.

A4.text: The number of neutrons may vary to form different isotopes, and energy levels may differ, resulting in different nuclear isomers.

A5.text: The number of protons in the nucleus is the defining property of an element, and is referred to as the atomic number (represented by the symbol Z).

A6.text: Isotopes of a given element have the same atomic number (number of protons) and differ in the number of neutrons.

A7.text: Each atomic number identifies a specific element, but not the isotope; an atom of a given element may have a wide range in its number of neutrons.

A8.text: An atom is composed of a positively charged nucleus, with a cloud of negatively charged electrons surrounding it, bound together by electrostatic force.
